item.title: My Books of 2019
item.description: Reading has always been a big part of my life and 2019 was a big year in terms of reading for me. I was able to increase the number of book I read from 14 books in 2018 to 19 in 2019 (that’s a 35% increase). And I read really interesting books as well - both fiction and non-fiction. Below is the list of books that I read in the year 2019 organized into fiction and non-fiction which some highlights on the books that really stood out to me.

item.title: Immigr8: Improving the journey of Migrant workers to Canada using design thinking
item.description: Executive Summary In our globalized world there is increased economic migration to high income countries like Canada. Economic migrants face the problem of finding relevant information without wasting precious time. The concept of a crowdsourced AI platform was proposed as a solution - by providing personalized information based on the user’s unique profile. A multi-sided business model was designed with big picture numbers showing profitability in 3 years. Challenge To explore and identity opportunities for innovation along the Migrant worker’s immigration journey, to ideate and evaluate solutions and to create a strategy for the implementation of the tested strategy.

item.title: Cupra Vision: A vision of sports driving
item.description: Summary CUPRA is an offshoot of the spanish automobile manufacturer. As a relatively new automobile brand, a major objective is to find ways to stand out in the market by finding a niche for themselves. Targeting sport driving aficionados means creating experiences that they are able to connect with. In this project, we created a concept of sports driving using digital and connectivity technology called Cupra Vision. Challenge What does the vision of an individualised CUPRA sports driving experience look like?

item.title: Walkable: Designing a walking experience to discover neighbourhoods in Barcelona
About Yinka Adesesan
item.description: I’m a business designer with a background in visual communication, UX design and technology education. I help global organisations capture, create and communicate with clarity using design thinking. I’m currently spending my days helping fortune 1000 companies design better products at DMI. In my evenings, I’m finding ways to help Nigerian self-taught designers level up their design skills using initiatives like LogoMarch. On weekends, I read hard science fiction and build tech things using no-code tools.
